chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: Prepare a successful deployment of &aa; on your system by carefully considering the following items:

step.para: Determine the applications to profile. Read more on this in .
Build the needed profiles as roughly outlined in . Check the results and adjust the profiles when necessary.
Update your profiles whenever your environment changes or you need to react to security events logged by the reporting tool of &aa;. Refer to .

sect1.title: Enabling and Disabling &aa;
sect1.para:
&aa; is configured to run by default on any fresh installation of
&productname;. There are two ways of toggling the status of &aa;:

listitem.para: Disable or enable &aa; by removing or adding its boot script to the sequence of scripts executed on system boot. Status changes are applied on reboot.

Toggle the status of &aa; in a running system by switching it off or on using the &yast; &aa; Control Panel. Changes made here are applied instantaneously. The Control Panel triggers a stop or start event for &aa; and removes or adds its boot script in the system's boot sequence.

sect1.para: To disable &aa; permanently (by removing it from the sequence of scripts executed on system boot) proceed as follows:

step.para: Mark apparmor by clicking its row in the list of services, then click Enable/Disable in the lower part of the window. Check that Enabled changed to Disabled in the apparmor row.

sect1.para: Toggle the status of &aa; in a running system by using the &aa; Configuration window. These changes take effect when you apply them and survive a reboot of the system. To toggle the status of &aa;, proceed as follows:

step.para: Start &yast;, select &aa; Configuration, and click Settings in the main window.
Enable &aa; by checking Enable &aa; or disable &aa; by deselecting it.
Click Done in the &aa; Configuration window.

sect1.title: Choosing Applications to Profile
sect1.para: You only need to protect the programs that are exposed to attacks in your particular setup, so only use profiles for those applications you actually run. Use the following list to determine the most likely candidates:
To find out which processes are currently running with open network ports and might need a profile to confine them, run aa-unconfined as &rootuser;.

example.title: Output of aa-unconfined
example.screen: 19848 /usr/sbin/cupsd not confined 19887 /usr/sbin/sshd not confined 19947 /usr/lib/postfix/master not confined 1328 /usr/sbin/smbd confined by '/usr/sbin/smbd (enforce)'

sect1.para: Each of the processes in the above example labeled not confined might need a custom profile to confine it. Those labeled confined by are already protected by &aa;.

sect1.title: Building and Modifying Profiles
sect1.para: &aa; on &productname; ships with a preconfigured set of profiles for the most important applications. In addition, you can use &aa; to create your own profiles for any application you want.

There are two ways of managing profiles. One is to use the graphical front-end provided by the &yast; &aa; modules and the other is to use the command line tools provided by the &aa; suite itself. The main difference is that &yast; supports only basic functionality for &aa; profiles, while the command line tools let you update/tune the profiles in a more fine-grained way.
For each application, perform the following steps to create a profile:

step.para: As &rootuser;, let &aa; create a rough outline of the application's profile by running aa-genprof PROGRAM_NAME.
Outline the basic profile by running &yast; Security and Users &aa; Configuration Manually Add Profile and specifying the complete path to the application you want to profile.
A new basic profile is outlined and put into learning mode, which means that it logs any activity of the program you are executing, but does not yet restrict it.
Run the full range of the application's actions to let &aa; get a very specific picture of its activities.
Let &aa; analyze the log files generated in by typing S in aa-genprof.
&aa; scans the logs it recorded during the application's run and asks you to set the access rights for each event that was logged. Either set them for each file or use globbing.

Depending on the complexity of your application, it might be necessary to repeat and . Confine the application, exercise it under the confined conditions, and process any new log events. To properly confine the full range of an application's capabilities, you might be required to repeat this procedure often.
When you finish aa-genprof, your profile is set to enforce mode. The profile is applied and &aa; restricts the application according to it.

If you started aa-genprof on an application that had an existing profile that was in complain mode, this profile remains in learning mode upon exit of this learning cycle. For more information about changing the mode of a profile, refer to
and .

sect1.para: Test your profile settings by performing every task you need with the application you confined. Normally, the confined program runs smoothly and you do not notice &aa; activities. However, if you notice certain misbehavior with your application, check the system logs and see if &aa; is too tightly confining your application. Depending on the log mechanism used on your system, there are several places to look for &aa; log entries:
To adjust the profile, analyze the log messages relating to this application again as described in . Determine the access rights or restrictions when prompted.

sect1.title: Updating Your Profiles
sect1.para: Software and system configurations change over time. As a result, your profile setup for &aa; might need some fine-tuning from time to time. &aa; checks your system log for policy violations or other &aa; events and lets you adjust your profile set accordingly. Any application behavior that is outside of any profile definition can be addressed by aa-logprof. For more information, see .
